data.name: paragraph
data.body: The phenomenon of electromagnetic induction has led to significant technological advancements, notably in generating alternating currents (AC).

data.name: paragraph
data.body: As discussed earlier, one way to generate an electric current in a loop is by changing its orientation or effective area. When a coil spins in a magnetic field $B$, the effective area of the loop becomes $A \cos \theta$, where $\theta$ is the angle between $A$ and $B$. This concept is fundamental to the operation of a basic AC generator, converting mechanical energy into electrical energy.

data.name: paragraph
data.body: The essential components of an AC generator include a coil mounted on a rotor shaft, with the coil's axis perpendicular to the magnetic field's direction. This coil, the armature, rotates in a uniform magnetic field, inducing an electric current. The ends of the coil connect to an external circuit using slip rings and brushes

data.name: paragraph
data.body: In commercial generators, mechanical energy for rotation is often sourced from water in hydroelectric generators or steam in thermal generators. Nuclear fuel may also power nuclear generators. Modern generators can output up to 500 MW, lighting millions of 100 W bulbs! Coils typically stay stationary while electromagnets rotate. Rotation frequency is around 50 Hz in India and 60 Hz in countries like the USA.
